posts.title: Count(*) vs Count(1) in SQL.
posts.bodyofcontent:
What They Do:

COUNT(*): This function simply counts all the rows in a table, no matter what. It doesn’t care about NULL values or anything else. It just wants to know how many rows there are.

COUNT(1): This function also counts all the rows in a table. The `1` is just a constant and does not refer to any specific column; it’s merely a placeholder. The database engine treats it the same way as `COUNT(*)`.

Performance Talk:
When it comes to performance, there’s usually not much of a difference between the two. Modern databases are pretty smart and can handle both just fine. Some folks say `COUNT(1)` might be a tad faster in certain older databases because it’s counting a simple constant value, but honestly, the difference is usually so small that it doesn’t matter much.
posts.endnotecontent: You can read all of my blogs for free at : thebigdataengineer.com

drafts.title: This is how you can present you Microproject Creatively
drafts.bodyofcontent:
Hello I am Ronak

As this page (berony) is the initiative from the student who is currently java full stack and angular 18 as front end framework with typescript .

And welcome to my Story , I have done a angualar project where i used for now a json as a database where i can post,read and update my stories any time and any where.

This Page provides me a lot of exposure to the new minds in the world and the creative person i can collaborate and work more efficiently.
